Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Looking at the log, I can see the user is switching between Microsoft Word, Google Chrome, and Adobe Acrobat. Each time they switch, it seems like they're moving to a different task.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: For example, switching from Word to Chrome implies they're checking email, then switching back to Word or Excel suggests they're resuming their document work or budget updates.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So, I think each time they start a new application or switch windows, it's a new case.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The raw actions like 'FOCUS,' 'TYPING,' 'SAVE,' 'SWITCH,' 'CLICK,' etc., need to be translated into more descriptive names. For example, 'FOCUS' in Word could be 'Editing Document,' 'TYPING' with specific keys could be 'Typing Text,' 'SAVE' is 'Saving Document,' 'SWITCH' between apps is 'Switching Applications,' 'CLICK' actions can become 'Clicking Action' or more specific like 'Opening Email.'

Name: Validation - PE
Text: I should aim for standardized names that capture the essence of the activity without being too granular. Maybe group similar actions together. For example, all typing actions can be 'Typing Text,' and all save actions can be 'Saving Document.'

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - IND
Text: Each application switch indicates a new case, and the activities are named based on the actions performed in each application.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Each event should have Case ID, Activity Name, Timestamp. I can also include the Application and Window Title as additional attributes for context. This will help in process analysis as analysts can see which applications and documents are involved in each case.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: The event log should tell a story of the user's work sessions. Looking at the log, the user works on documents in Word, switches to Chrome to handle emails, then switches back to Word or Excel for more document work. Each time they switch, it's a new case.
